title: stacey dooley arms dealing
story: Instead, the Arkansas mum became a gun dealer – negotiating international arms and weapons deals worth up to £. billion a time.In BBC’s Stacey Dooley: Face to Face with Arms Dealers, which airs today, the Strictly star investigates whether the weapons they sell are protecting or killing us.It takes her to the southern state where more than half the population own a gun.But its not just the local market who are interested in what Gretchens business, Thor Global Defence Group, can offer.America is the worlds biggest exporter of arms and the industry is worth £billion a year to the US economy, employing , workers and Gretchens company sells to more than  countries - over half in the world.If someone wanted a -feet shipping container of AKs, Gretchen is who you go to for it.At her workplace, which looks like a gun shop with a shooting range, she reveals she has grenade launchers stored downstairs.Gretchen says using guns is justied because it’s “sheer defence”.“As an American we are born and grow up being taught about guns,” she tells Stacey.“I can’t imagine living in a place that I didn’t have the right to strap a gun on and not be a victim.”I wont go to London - its too dangerous. You guys have a real problem with terrorist attacks, rapes are very high, stabbings.Gretchen has no military background but reveals she decided to swap domesticity for le in the male-dominated and secretive arms industry after her brother, Alan, narrowly avoided death in the   terror attacks in .They were watching the attacks on the news when they realised that Alan could have been one of the planes that crashed into the Twin Towers, killing everyone on board.I didnt know where he was, and that was the worst thing, thats when it kicks in, says Gretchen. We didnt know how many were taken. We didnt know anything.“I’m frightened I can’t defend the people I love. I pray for the best and prepare for the worst.But it is absolute sheer defence. I want military to have quality weapons, and defend people like you.”Although she admits she is “frightened of guns”, Stacey is given a lesson in shooting a rle and Thor’s most prestigious gun, nicknamed Pandora.She says: “I feel really uneasy and awkward around guns” but Gretchen reassures her, saying: “You’re getting the same training sessions our kids go through. We are going to teach you right along with our children, with my daughter, she is .If the time comes you have to drop the camera and pick up a weapon you’ll know what to do with it.”Despite her initial reluctance, Stacey surprised herself with her “delighted” reaction when she hit the targets. She also concedes that she does feel safer when in dangerous places with people who carry guns.Stacey sees eight-year-old Richie, the son of the companys CEO fire a gun. He tells her it feels awesomeand that he wants to be a sniper when he grows up.Stacey also visits the manufacturers where she meets factory owner, Wade, who takes her through the process of producing weapons to meet Thor’s specic requirements.Wade explains the serial number of the gun means it can always be traced. If the gun is used for criminal activity, Thor will stop selling to that client.The company takes two weeks to produce  rles, which cost around £, each.To test them, each gun is fired  times as part of the companys “internal policy”, before it is wiped to remove fingerprints, packaged and sent to the client.Only three components are needed to make a bullet: the case, powder and projectile.Although making weapons is a vital part of their work the most important part is the paperwork, whichnot completed correctly could see Gretchen face serious consequences.She said: “We follow the rules. We can lose our licence or go to jail. It’s a federal offence. It could be  years per weaponpaperwork isn’t right.”During filming for the documentary, the terrorist attacks at mosques in Christchurch, New Zealand, which killed  people take place.Thor were in the midst of organising an order to a gun shop in New Zealand where the terrorists bought their firearms.Askedthe attack proves selling arms has dangerous repercussions, Payton says: “I don’t blame all car drivers for one drunk driver. You will find one [bad] person in every business, only we sell things that could cause massacres.”BBC Three’s Stacey Dooley: Face to Face with Arms Dealers is available online on BBC. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: But I’m afraid it isn’t enough — not nearly enough.If the BBC is to continue to be funded by the taxpayer, it must slash costs and scrap the licence fee altogether.This year has been an annus horribilis for the Beeb.Its dficulties began in February with the launch of BBC Scotland, a new channel north of the border with an annual budget of £million.Unfortunately, very few people have been tuning in.BBC Scotland’s flagship current affairs programme, The Nine, is watched by just , people — even fewer than Alex Salmond’s weekly chat show on Russia Today.But it’s more than tune in to The Seven, BBC Scotland’s nightly news show.MOST READ IN OPINION" data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   NINTCHDBPICT.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentTHE SUN SAYS Boris Johnson is not a dictator, he is defending democracy from Remoaners " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   JBM_COMP-rod-liddle.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentROD LIDDLE Parliament works AGAINST the people so BoJo is right to threaten to suspend it " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   NINTCHDBPICT.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentDANIEL HANNAN Its not Boris putting the Government at risk - its those deranged Remainers " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   NINTCHDBPICT.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentTHE SUN SAYS Remainers have no right to complain now that the tables have turned " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   MB-COMP-JANEMOORE.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentJANE MOORE Coleen will forgive silly fool Wayne again after club girl lt photograph " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   NINTCHDBPICT-e.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" THE SUN SAYS Signing away powers to get Brexit over the line could cost Boris his job The Seven is one of  programmes on the new channel that at certain points between February  and June  had zero viewers, according to the British Audience Research Board.That’s quite an achievement, given that Scotland has a population of five-and-a-half million and the average viewer north of the border spends three hours and  minutes a day watching television.Then, in June, the BBC announced it would be breaking its promise to provide free TV licences to the over-s.The Director-General, Tony Hall, agreed to take on that responsibility from the Government as a condition of the BBC’s Royal Charter being renewed in .According to the terms of the deal, the Corporation would be able to put up the licence fee each year and, in , it would fund free TV licences for pensioners from June , .The Beeb’s Royal Charter was duly renewed and the licence fee went up in , in  and again in .Yet apparently it can no longer afford to keep its pledge. From next June, only those over-s on pension credit will be eligible for free TV licences — just one in five people.That means .million pensioners, including more than , service veterans, will have to find £. a yearthey want to continue watching television.To add insult to injury, the BBC then disclosed how much money it is paying its stars.Anti-Brexit activist and Match Of The Day presenter Gary Lineker is on £,,, Graham Norton is on £, and Claudia Winkleman is on £,.Lineker’s salary alone would pay for more than , TV licences.Asthat wasn’t bad enough, earlier this month the Beeb said it intends to spend £million on an advertising campaign to attract young viewers and listeners.That’s more than the annual budget of Radio .It’s particularly high, given that the BBC can advertise on its own TV channels and radio stations for free. Apparently, the money is going to be spent on targeting young people on social media.Are we really supposed to believe that the BBC cannot afford to pay for pensioners’ TV licences, but can fritter away £million on Facebook adverts There’s almost nothing Auntie won’t stoop to in its desperate pursuit of the “yoof” audience.It has earmarked £million to promote its new Sounds app — including spending £, to transform the London Eye into the “London Ear” — and poured money into a series of increasingly tawdry podcasts, such as Gemma Collins talking about her le, a reality-show round-up called Reality Tea, and Unexpected Fluids, in which teenagers tell embarrassing ­stories about when sex goes wrong.It’s all a far cry from Lord Reith’s mission to explain.No doubt the BBC is concerned about how few young people it manages to attract — and this manests itself in other ways, too, such as its massive investment in apps and podcasts and its extensive online coverage of ITV’s Love Island.Last year, Ofcom revealed that  to -year-olds are spending an average of an hour and  minutes per day consuming BBC content, which is about half the amount for all age groups.Even more worrying for the Corporation, one in eight young Brits consumes no BBC content at all. Why should they fork out £. for the licence fee, particularly as many of them will already be paying for subscription TV services The fundamental problem the Beeb faces is that consumers are becomingly increasingly accustomed to paying for the TV content they want to watch and resent having to pay a mandatory flat tax to a single provider.The equivalent would beeveryone who owns a phone, tablet or laptop had to pay £. for an “internet licence” to fund Apple’s iTunes, regardless of whether or not they use the service.It’s time to do away with the licence fee — for everyone, not just the over-s.That would mean stripping down the state-funded parts of the BBC to its core news and current affairs output and funding that out of general taxation.It should sell off its profitable private isions — such as BBC Studios, which has annual revenues of more than £billion — and plough the money into creating its own subscription service.With its global brand recognition and unrivalled back catalogue, not to mention its reputation for high-quality drama, the BBC could easily compete with commercial providers such as Netflix and Amazon Prime.Promising to scrap the licence fee would surely be a vote-winner for Boris Johnson.What other election pledge would save nearly every British household £. a year No s, no buts. When it comes to renewing the BBC’s Royal Charter, it’s time to say: “No deal.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris has been a revelation since he took over brexit but signing away powers to get it over the line could cost him his job
story: Delivering on the referendum ought to make Nigel Farage’s Brexit Party redundant and ensure a Tory election win. But binning the toxic Irish backstop might not be enough eventhe EU agrees.There is plenty in Theresa May’s deal to bind our hands even after we have left.The Sun would still prefer a deal. But Farage will capitalise, understandably so,Boris signs away any sovereign powers in haste to get Brexit over the line. That could yet cost him power.This may all be moot. We do not see Brussels nor the Irish PM scrapping the backstop they have treated as holy writ.But when his own allies like Iain Duncan Smith warn him not to be satisfied solely with that, Boris must listen.WHO’S up for more years of bitter Brexit ision and political paralysis Not Leavers, who were sick of it long ago and are furious their vote hasn’t been fulfilled. title: remainers porkie pies trade deals
story: By drawing his excited opponents into making accusations about yet more of Boris’s “porky pies”, he has skilfully drawn attention to the point he really wanted to make — that there are huge global opportunities for British food exportersonly we are prepared to make concessions in opening up our own food markets to the world.In fact,we start exporting pork pies to the Far East we will only be ing to what we were doing more than  years ago.In , Melton Mowbray bakers Evans  Hill reported they had received a large order of pork pies from Borneo — which is even further from Britain than Thailand.If we could do it then, without modern refrigeration, we can surely do it now. As Boris was arguing, the real barriers to trade are not practical ones — they are taxes and regulations.Remainers continually lecture us on the benefits of free trade with the EU — and they are right to do so. Hardly anyone really wants to leave without a deal. If we do have to take that route it will surely not be long before discussions on a free trade deal recommence.Yet those same Remainers bizarrely retreat in horror when anyone suggests we do a free trade deal with the US. “But we’ll have to eat chlorinated chicken,” they complain, as well as GM “Frankenstein” food.As shown by their failure yesterday to agree on a common course of action to thwart Brexit, Remainers are bumbling along in a state of confusion.But nothing demonstrates this better than their contradictory approach to free trade. They seem to think it a great benefit to the country when conducted with the EU, but a route to national disastercarried out with any other country.The charge that anyone will be forced to eat chlorinated chicken or GM foods is, needless to say, a far bigger porky pie than anything Boris has said on the subject.It is far from certain that a Johnson Government, when engaged in trade talks with the US, will make the concessions allowing these products into UK markets, butit does, then UK shoppers will continue to have a choice.They will still be able to buy chicken produced in Britain or the EU, or they will be able to choose to eat American chicken.I certainly have no fear of eating chicken which has been washed in chlorine. The idea that it is “dangerous” has been thoroughly debunked. Each of us ingests far more chlorine through drinking water than we ever would do through eating US-produced chicken.As for GM foods, we already eat them, vegans especially. The EU allows imports of GM soyafor simple practical reasons. Most of it is grown in the Americas and too many growers there use GM seed for non-GM soya to be sold as a separate product.If we want free trade we are not going to achieve it just by persuading other countries to open their markets to us. No, we will have to make the concession of opening our markets to them too. But there is no reason to be frightened.True, there are some products which need to be banned from sale for genuine health and safety reasons. But most of the EU’s food product standards are really just a form of protectionism in disguise, dreamed up to block competition for European farmers.If we do post-Brexit trade deals with the US and other countries — and in the process do away with the EU’s protectionist tarfs and product standards — some UK producers would suffer.But others would prosper as they enjoyed access to new export markets. Overall, as is almost always the case when trade barriers are taken down, we would benefit. Strong industries would grow and consumers would enjoy greater choice and lower prices.Boris’s vision of a global British pork pie industry shows the dference between him and the political opponents who spent much of yesterday scheming over how to stop him taking Britain out of the EU.While his glass is half full, theirs is half empty.They are driven by a pathological fear of le outside the EU.It is not that they have any great enthusiasm for the EU. After all, I haven’t heard one of them make a convincing case why the EU is an institution to be admired. title: stromboli volcano erupts in front of terrified tourists

title: who is lord young resigned brexit
story: Heres everything we know about the Conservative politician...George Samuel Knatchbull Young, Baron Young of Cookham was a Conservative MP representing North West Hampshire from , and before that Ealing Acton.He is a former Etonian and graduated from the University of Oxford with a degree in Philosophy, Politics and Economics.He was active in student politics while at Oxford, holding ious offices in the Oxford University Conservative Association and being elected to the Standing Committee of the Oxford Union.Young has served in Cabinet three times, as Secretary of State for Transport from  to , as the Leader of the House of Commons and Lord Privy Seal from  to  and as Chief Whip of the House of Commons from  to .As a Conservative Party minister, Lord Young had served under Margaret Thatcher, John Major and David Cameron.Young quit the Commons during the  election and was created a le peer - a title which guarantees Young a seat in the House of Lords.On August  Young resigned as a whip in the House of Lords over Boris Johnsons decision to prorogue parliament.In his resignation letter, Young writes: Following the announcement that parliament is to be prorogued in the week beginning September th, and not due to reconvene until October th, I am afraid I cannot continue to serve in your team in the Lords.Young goes on to claim that his resignation is not primarily about Brexit, although he does think that Boris Johnsons do or die approach to leaving on October  is rash, and that more time could be procured should need be.More time may be needed to get the Withdrawal Agreement through both Houses with the scrutiny it deserves, he writes.Young says he is very unhappy with the timing andof the prorogation of Parliament, as well as the motivation behind the move.He says he is unpersuaded by the reasons given for that decision [to prorogue Parliament] which I believe risks undermining the fundamental role of parliament at a critical time in our history, and reinforces the view that the government may not have the confidence of the House for its Brexit policy.In his letter of resignation, Young insists that he is not part of any remainer plot.

title: mmr jabs uk loses measles free status
story: Britain lost its elimination status just  days ago while Albania, Czech Republic and Greece also lapsed in the last year.Meanwhile, every region in the world is experiencing an increase in the number of cases of the vaccine-preventable disease that can kill or disable children, the World Health Organisation warned today.Nearly three times as many cases were reported globally from January to July this year than in the same period in , the WHO said.Europe has seen a surge in cases since , with around , cases reported for the first half of this year - already more than that recorded in the whole of  - ,.As of the end of ,  countries had achieved or sustained measles elimination, the European Regional Verication Commission for Measles and Rubella Eliminationsaid.The UK was added to the list in  by the World Health Organisation .The independent  of experts, established by WHO, met in June in Warsaw, Poland, to evaluate reports from  countries.It comes as WHO said misinformation about vaccines, particularly that shared on social media, is as contagious and dangerous as the diseases it helps to spread.Dr Gunter Pfaff, chair of the RVC, said: Re-establishment of measles transmission is concerning.If high immunisation coverage is not achieved and sustained in every community, both children and adults will suffer unnecessarily and some will tragically die.Professor Martin Marshall, vice-chairman of the Royal College of GPs, said the findings were disheartening.While take-up of the MMR vaccination across the UK are still high, it is not high enough, and we have actually seen a small decline in recent years, he said.It is clear that we are still suffering from entirely debunked claims around MMR that were perpetuated in the nineties - and are now resurgent on social media and other online s.MEASLES is a highly infectious viral illness that can sometimes lead to very serious complications.It can cause things like pneumonia and encephalitis - both of which can kill or leave people seriously disabled for the rest of their lives.Now, experts are calling for measles vaccinations to be made mandatory in certain countries.Its given in two doses as part of the NHS childhood vaccination programme.The first jab is given to kids at around  months old, while a second dose is administered at around three years, four months.There is no link at all between having the MMR vaccine and autism - even in children who have other risk factors for the condition, scientists confirmed back in March.Thats the conclusion of a nationwide study of all children born in Denmark to Danish-born mums between  and .Last week, we revealed that anti-vaxxer parents were holding measles parties to give their kids the deadly virus.Work is continuing across the NHS to ensure messages about the safety, and le-saving nature of vaccinations are heard, and it is encouraging that WHO has increased its focus on measles elimination and upgraded action to address the challenges which have allowed this deadly virus to persist in countries including the UK.This, alongside a commitment by our Government to tackle a wave of dangerous anti-vax messages being shared online - particularly via social media - will hopefully go a long way in helping the country get back on track and regain our measles-free status.It comes as WHO welcomed a decision by social media company Pinterest to only provide evidence-based information from leading health experts to its users in a bid to tackle health misinformation.The company will give users resources from WHO, the Centres for Disease Control and Prevention , the American Academy of Pediatrics , and the WHO-established Vaccine Safety Netwhen they search for a related term.We see this as a critical issue and one that needs our collective effort to protect peoples health and lives.

title: coloured tattoos leak toxic metals lymph nodes
story: Researchers have discovered that nickel and chromium, which are allergens, are shed from a tattoo needle when a white pigment is used.The pigment - called titanium dioxide - is often mixed into brighter colours such as blue, green and red.But the new study, from the European Synchrotron Radiation Facilityin Grenoble, France, found that it can cause the needle to erode and so tiny metal particles can enter the skin.Those particles then travel to the lymph nodes, which are small glands that store white blood cells - responsible for killing invading organisms.The researchers claim that the identication of these metals inside the pigment could explain why some people suffer bad reactions to tattoos.In , a study by New York University found that  per cent of people had reported suffering an adverse reaction to a tattoo.But until quite recently, experts had thought it was to do with the inks.Previous research had shown that there were metal nanoparticles in the lymph nodes of tattooed people.They ranged from  nanometres long, or as small as DNA molecule, to two micrometres long, which is about the size of a bacterium cell.Nanoparticles are considered more hazardous than larger particles because they have surface area per volume, which can cause a higher release of toxic chemicals.The European Chemicals Agencywarned back in  that some tattoo inks could be toxic, and has called for the banning of the potentially-deadly substances.The organisations report claims that the toxic ink could cause long-lasting skin problems, as well as increasing the risk of cancer.Other side effects include serious allergic reactions to the suspect ink and painful itching which can last for years.Red inks were described as the most dangerous, but blue, green and black inks also came under fire.The agency said: “Many reports show concerns for public health stemming from the composition of inks used for tattooing.“The most severe concerns are allergies caused by the substances in the inks and possible carcinogenic, mutagenic or reproductive toxic effects.”The team at the ESRF wanted to establish whether there was a link between the metal nanoparticles found in the lymph nodes of tattooed people.ESRF scientist Ines Schreiver, who co-authored the research, said: We were following up on our previous study, by trying to find the link between iron, chromium and nickel and the colouring of the inks.After studying several human tissue samples and finding metallic components, we realised that there must be something .Then we thought of testing the needle and that was our eureka moment.They began studying ink sample under an intense X-ray and found that when tattoo ink contains titanium dioxide, the needle can erode.The research, published in the journal Particle and Fibre Toxicology, found that it doesnt happen with carbon black ink, which is softer.Co-author Hiram Castillo added: There is more to tattoos than meet the eye.It is not only about the cleanliness of the parlour, the sterilisation of the equipment or even about the pigments.Now we find that the needle wear also has an impact in your body.These are long-term effects which can only be assessed in long-term epidemiological studies that monitor the health of thousands of people over decades.

title: portsmouth university student bar shuts
story: Undergraduates used to have a reputation for heavy drinking at the union bar.But The Waterhole Bar at the University of Portsmouth has seen a massive drop in alcohol sales and is to be turned into a “social space” with a coffee shop and microwaves.Alcohol sales are down  per cent year on year for the past four years and it has lost more than half its total sales.A study in September  by the National Union of Students found one in five university students don’t drink alcohol.Portsmouth Universitys Vice-Chancellor Graham Galbraith said: “We recognise that student tastes have changed in recent years and most students who want to drink alcohol would prefer to do so at other city venues.Only a minority of students have been using the Waterhole bar and we’re aware that many avoid it.Students’ Union President Helena Schofield added: “We are sad to see the bar go but we understand that it’s not financially viable to keep it open.”We’re excited to hear student ideas on what the new space should bring to the experience of students here in Portsmouth.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. some  miles southeast of Irans capital Tehran.Iranian satellite launches had been anticipated before the end of the year.In July, Irans Information and Communications Technology Minister Mohammad Javad Azari Jahromi told the AP that Tehran planned three more launches this year, two for satellites that do remote-sensing work and another that handles communications.The Nahid- is reportedly the telecommunication satellite, which authorities plan to have in orbit for two-and-a-half months. Nahid in Farsi means Venus.The satellite, which had Irans first foldable solar , was supposed to be in a low orbit around the Earth for some two-and-a-half months.The semi-official Mehr news agency quoted Jahromi on Aug.  as saying that the Nahid- was ready to be delivered to Irans Defense Ministry, signalling a launch date for the satellite likely loomed.Irans National Week of Government, during which Tehran often inaugurates new projects, began August .Earlier today, Irans Defence Minister General Amir Hatami told the state-run IRNA news agency that the countrys satellite activities were being done in a transparent way, responding to AP and other foreign media reporting on activity at the space centre. Whenever activity and research bear successful results, we will announce the good news, Hatami said.Iran at times in the past hasnt acknowledged failed launches.The apparent attempt to launch the Nahid- comes after two failed satellite launches of the Payam and Doosti in January and February.A separate fire at the Imam Khomeini Space Centre in February also killed three researchers, authorities said at the time.I think it is certainly an image problem, said Michael Connell, an Iran analyst at the Arlington, Virginia-based nonprofit research organisation CNA.I think its going to embarrass the Iranian space agency. On the other hand though, getting a satellite into space ... takes time.Tehran also says it doesnt violate the UN as it only called upon Tehran not to conduct such tests.The tests have taken on new importance to the US amid the maximalist approach to Iran taken by President Donald Trumps administration.Tensions have been high between the countries since Trump unilaterally withdrew the U.S. from Irans nuclear deal over a year ago and imposed sanctions, including on Irans oil industry.Iran recently has begun to break the accord itself while trying to push Europe to help it sell oil abroad.The State Department did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

title: remainer speaker john bercow blasted
story: Jacob Rees-Mogg hit out at Bercow after he said the PM caused “constitutional outrage” for getting the Queen to approve his shutdown of Parliament.The Brexiteer MP said the most constitutionally improper thing that happened yesterday was the Speakers intervention.He fumed: I think the outrage is phoney and it is created by people who dont want us to leave the European Union and are trying very hard to overturn the referendum result and dont want the benefits of leaving the European Union.He added: Parliament wasnt going to be sitting for most of this time anyway. This is completely constitutional and proper.This is not the first time Bercow has clashed with Brexiteer MPs.Earlier this month Bercow vowed he would fight any attempt to prorogue Parliament with every bone in my body.Mr Bercow said: “If there is an attempt to circumvent, to bypass or - to take place between September  to October  - was given the green light.Boris bold move to block MPs from sitting in Parliament for around five weeks over conference season will give Remainers less time to launch new plots to stop us leaving on October .MPs would come back for a Queens Speech on October  under the plans, just two weeks before were due to leave the EU.That would leave just days for a possible vote of no confidence in Boris, or for rebel MPs to pass a law to push back the Brexit date.

title: british brexit chief in serious talks over backstop
story: David Frost was sent to meet EU chiefs and find a solution to the biggest stumbling block in Brexit with just a month remaining to the October  deadline.EU Attitudes towards a new deal have softened in recent weeks with the PM making a good impression with his statecraft at the G summit in Biarritz.Dutch Foreign Minister Stephan Blok said progress was being made – but there were still some way to go before a new deal can be sorted.He explained: I know that there have been serious talks in Brussels but we are not there yet.”The backstop was a mechanism suggested by May’s team that would keep the sensitive Irish border open after Brexit by tying Britain to EU trading rules – and preserve the Good Friday Agreement.An EU diplomat said: They presented nothing concrete but are tonext week and said they want to test ideas with the Commission.In the meantime, Johnson has taken everyone by surprise and put the opposition firmly on the spot. He is pushing for an early election - we just dont knowbefore, or after Oct..Boris has warned the bloc that Britain will be leaving “do or die” by the Halloween deadline.However, he has repeatedly stated that he wants a deal – but refuses to compromise on the backstop.UK Sherpa Frost apparently told Euro parliament officials that a deal was the governments “first option”, according to the FT.Boris’ tough stance has appeared to have finally shown Brussels that the PM won’t be bullied like his predecessor was.His meetings with top Brexit players at the G including Emmanuel Macron and Donald Tusk impressed the EU.But they are now fully aware that while the PM does not want No Deal - he will pursue it they do not play ball.Bo-Jos decision to suspend Parliament has also caused ripples in Brussels with Brexit chiefs criticising the bold move.Guy Verhofstadt described Boris’ plan as “sinister”.He ranted on Twitter: “Taking back control has never looked so sinister. As a fellow parliamentarian, my solidarity with those fighting for their voices to be heard.“Suppressing debate on profound choices is unlikely to help deliver a stable future EU - UK relationship.”While the EU’s chief negotiator Michel Barner said: “PM Boris Johnson has said that the UK will leave the EU on  Oct.“In all circumstances, the EU will continue to protect the interests of its citizens and companies, as well as the conditions for peace and stability on the island of Ireland. It is our duty  our responsibility.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A senior cabinet minister has been slapped down by Number  after being caught on camera apparently blurting out the reasons for Boris Johnson shutting down Parliament. The Prime Minister announced he was going to reboot Parliament in September, slashing the time MPs have to debate and block his Brexit plan.Number  say they want to hold a Queen’s Speech to set out their raft of domestic policies, and insist the timing has nothing to do with Brexit. But Johnson leads a minority government - and every sitting day increases the chances of his Brexit plan being defeated by opponents in Parliament. And today Number  said Defence Secretary Ben Wallace misspoke when he was filmed in an unguarded moment apparently admitting the move was about Brexit after all. Mr Wallace was seen speaking to French Defence Minister Florence Parly moments before a meeting of European counterparts in Helsinki, in footage broadcast by the BBC.    Ms Parly reportedly asked Mr Wallace about the plan to ‘prorogue’ Parliament. “Parliament has been very good at saying what it doesn’t want,” he said. “But it has been awful at saying what it does want, that’s the reality.” He went on: “So you know, eventually any leader has to, you know, try.” “I don’t know what the outcome of it…” he said, bursting into laughter. “You know…politics.”    He went on to explain that the real reason it was necessary to shut down Parliament to get a Brexit plan through was because Johnson doesn’t have the majority he needs to stop it being blocked. “Our system is a winner takes all system,” he said. “If you win a parliamentary majority you control everything. You control the timetable. There is no written separation. So it’s…you pretty much are in command of the whole thing. “And we’ve suddenly found ourselves with no majority and a coalition, and that’s not easy for our system.” A Number  source said: “The Defence secretary misspoke and was not involved in discussions about the Queen’s speech. The Queen’s speech will allow us to set out an ambitious legislative programme to deliver on our domestic priorities such as tackling violent crime, investing in our health service and tackling the cost of living.” But SNP MP Joanna Cherry, who is leading a legal challenge to the shutdown, said the clip backed up her teamaposs claim.  She tweeted: I’ve drawn this admission to the attention of our legal team. Defence Secretary backs up what we contend - that prorogation of Parliament is for an improper purpose  therefore unlawful. Labour MP Wes Streeting said: Telling the truth is a disciplinary offence under Boris Johnson’s regime. And Independent Group for Change MP Chris Leslie said: The shabby pretence that closing Parliament is anything other than a device to thwart majority of MPs makes this constitutional abuse more insulting.If they’re going to use authoritarian powers, at least be honest about why! But maybe it’s the cover-up that will trip them up.

According to reports, the Prime Minister and his team at Number  were determined to keep their plans a secret until everything was done and dusted - but things didnapost quite go as they hoped. Three of Johnsonaposs ministers - Commons Leader Jacob Rees-Mogg , Lords Leader Baroness Natalie Evans and Chief Whip Mark Spencer - were sent to Balmoral to ask the Queen to suspend Parliament. However a leak, believed to have come from within Whitehall, meant word of their plans got out much earlier than planned.    According to the Times, this means Johnson had to bring his phone call with the Queen forward to tell her what he was planning so she didnapost read it in the news first.  The Times states: To the embarrassment of Downing Street, Boris Johnson had to bring forward a phone call to Her Majesty to ask her to prorogue Parliament so that she would know about it before the rest of the nation heard it on the news. However Number  has refused to confirm what time the phone call happened. The Monarch signed off the shock bid - which has prompted outrage among MPs and plunged Britain into a constitutional crisis - in the meeting at her summer retreat Balmoral.    It means Parliament will be suspended or aposproroguedapos for more than a month from September , sabotaging MPsapos efforts to block no-deal Brexit or vote no confidence in the government. According to Jacob Rees-Mogg , the Queen did not question Johnsonaposs request to shut down Parliament - and realistically would not have been able to. He said there was no chat, no debate after he flew to Balmoral to make the request, saying: The Queen says aposapprovedapos. That’s it. Some suggested the Queen should have blocked the aposprorogationapos, however she isnapost technically allowed to.  Royal expert Ingrid Seward, editor in chief of Majesty magazine, believes the Queen may not be happy about what she was forced to do , but knows she has to be above politics. She said: Her Majesty is in an uncomfortable position. As Head of State she acts for the Government of the day. That is her job. The constitution is working exactly as it should.  It is not a crisis as many people have said, but it is a very dficult chapter in the history of the constitution which was set by statue as a Bill of Rights in .  Having reigned for over  years, Her Majesty is sensitive to the wishes of her people and knows over this issue the nation is seriously ided.  She may not be happy and she may well be troubled by the latest turn of events. But she is above politics and always has been. Those close to Her Majesty say how much she dislikes being dragged into a potentially political minefield.  She has spent her time as Queen avoiding doing so.

Opposition peers are understood to be preparing for a fight after Boris Johnson gave them just seven days - or fewer - to sit before he shuts down Parliament.That will leave barely any time to rubber-stamp a law, expected to be tabled by MPs from next Tuesday, attempting to rule out a no-deal exit on October .Labour , Lib Dem and some Tory and Crossbench peers have repeatedly defeated the government in the House of Lords in recent years - especially over Brexit.In April they helped pass a law ruling out a no-deal Brexit despite sittings running late into the evening. But while Yvette Cooperaposs Bill got through despite filibustering, this time Lords sources fear delaying tactics will be directly sanctioned by the government. Weaposre in more unpredictable territory, a source said. I think weaposre heading for a couple of very long days and nights.    The Lords sees itself as the defender of the constitution. Given whataposs happened over the last few days, there may well be some people who decide this is their moment. One senior Lords source told ITV they were confident of getting a Bill through by Monday after next - with peers preparing for an emergency weekend sitting. If peers sit next Saturday itaposs thought it will be the first time since the Falklands War in . But another source told the Mirror that, while not impossible, it was unlikely. It comes after Boris Johnson announced Parliament will be suspended from September  - or even earlier - to October  despite the Brexit deadline. Despite the tight timetable, MPs bidding to thwart his no-deal Brexit are gearing up for a battle royale next week.    Labour confirmed it would stage an emergency debate as soon as the Commons s from the summer recess. The fast-tracked move, expected to be allowed by Speaker John Bercow, would pave the way for Parliament to try and pass a law blocking a no-deal Brexit. But they face a race against time to derail the Prime Minister’s bid to keep open the option of quitting the EU without an agreement. Shadow Trade Secretary Barry Gardiner admitted it would be “extremely dficult” to halt the Prime Minister’s attempt, following his decision to suspend Parliament from mid-September. He told the BBC: “It is going to be extremely dficult, that’s why the Government is disingenuous to say this is not about trying to stop us doing that. We will be seeking measures on Monday to try and have what is known as a Standing Order section  debate. We will seek to try and put through the appropriate legislation in this constrained timetable that the Government has now put before us.” Any Bill will have to be approved first by the Commons, then the Lords, then any dferences smoothed out in a process called ping pong. Normally that takes several months.    Tory former Chancellor Ken Clarke indicated he would back moves to stop Mr Johnson taking the UK out of the EU without an agreement. “I would do anything necessary to stop this country going through the childishly disastrous mistake of crashing out with no deal,” he vowed.But Commons leader Jacob Rees-Mogg blasted the “phoney” outrage over prorogation, saying: “Parliament wasn’t going to be sitting for most of this time anyway. This is completely constitutional and proper.There is going to be a lot of time to debate before October .”  Former Supreme Court judge Lord Sumption said that while it may be unconventional to prorogue Parliament as the Brexit deadline looms, the move was entirely legal. “I don’t think what the Prime Minister has said he is going to do is unlawful,” he added. Today James Graham - who wrote the hit play This House about Parliamentary shenanigans - claimed party leaders in the Lords could stop Parliament from being prorogued by refusing to doff their hats.

title: what brexit backstop northern ireland
story: NewsWhat is the Brexit backstop  Northern Ireland policy explainedBoris Johnson says hell take Britain out without a dealthe EU wont drop the backstop. So what is the backstop  We explain hereShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  AUG News "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for the purpose of sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBoris Johnson says he wants to agree a Brexit deal before Halloween - but thereaposs one thing standing in the way. The Northern Ireland backstop. Youaposve probably heard a lot about this mysterious backstop. But do you know what it means  We donapost blame younot, as the whole thing has been testing our brains for months. In fact, itaposs astonishing that the whole of Brexit has come down to boring technical jargon about customs arrangements. But we are where we are, and with a possible general election round the corner, itaposs vital you know what the debate is about. Here is the issue explained.  The aposbackstopapos is an insurance clause in the UKaposs -page Brexit deal with Brussels, which was signed by Theresa May in November . If the deal is passed, EU rules continue in a transition period until  December . But after that, itaposs not known how we can avoid putting up checkpoints along the -mile border between Northern Irelandand the Republic . This situation - known as a hard border - would set Irish peace back decades and could trigger ato violence of the Troubles. It would reverse the Good Friday Agreement pact that allows anyone to cross the border with little more than a sign and a dferent-coloured road. So the backstop is designed to stop a hard border, no matter what.    Under the backstop, EU customs rules will be extended across the whole of the UK for a temporary period. This has infuriated Brexiteer MPs - who fear we will be a colony of Brussels, unable to sign trade deals around the world. It will kick in from  January no solution has been found for the Irish border. Britain has an alternative option, to trigger a one-off extension to the transition period for EU rules, instead of the backstop. Butit does kick in, it can only be ended by a joint committee - in other words, EU officials get a veto. And there is no time limit, meaningthe UK and EU canapost agree, we could be stuck in the backstop for a very long time. Why is it such a big problem  . It will stop the UK signing global trade deals    The UK cannot sign its own trade deals with other countries, like Australia and Japan,it is in a customs union with the EU. This is why Theresa May was adamant the UK must leave the EU customs union. The backstop, however, will keep us in that customs union in all but name.    Theresa May tried again and again to set a time limit on the backstop, but she was unsuccessful. First she wanted to set a firm end date of  December  - but the EU rejected it. . Then she wanted a mechanism for the UK to quit the backstop, no matter what Brussels says - but the EU rejected that too. Instead, there will be an independent committee to decidethe backstop can be terminated, with members from both the UK and EU. If this wasnapost bad enough it could be overseen by the European Court of Justice - the exact body Brexiteers are trying to leave. . It could treat Northern Ireland dferently  A backstop would force some checks on trade Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK. Boris Johnsonaposs DUP allies reject that - saying it breaks up the precious union of the UK. For all these reasons, Boris Johnson says we must get rid of the backstop entirely, rather than reshaping or editing it in a dferent form. Why canapost we just get rid of the backstop   Boris Johnson wants to replace the backstop with aposalternative arrangementsapos, to kick in at a later date, which ensure we donapostto a hard border. He has said these arrangements could include high-tech checks and apostrusted trader schemesapos to lessen bureaucracy. But critics say he has not been specic enough about what these arrangements actually are. And the delay to them kicking in would mean we had a period after Brexit with no insurance policy. Irish Premier Leo Varadkar has told Boris Johnson the backstop is necessary as a consequence of decisions taken by the UK government. And he said the EU was united in its view that the withdrawal agreement cannot be reopened. What did the EU offer before  In January , the House of Commons voted to send the backstop back to Brussels to be rewritten. Theresa May wanted to insert either a time limit a unilateral exit clause or mythical alternative arrangements. Now Boris Johnson wants to go further and scrap it completely, dealing with some of its issues later once Brexit has been assured. But the EU refused to scrap OR rewrite the backstop - because itaposs wrapped up in the -page Brexit deal. Instead, the EU offered to add assurances, like a legal codicil, and rewrite a much smaller political declaration on future trade. This stopped short of MPsapos demands to make legally binding changes to the backstop itself.

title: meet brit family trying save
story: NewsMeet the Brit family trying to save struggling teens on brink of suicideEXCLUSIVE: Dave Bush, we Sue, and daughter Jess, are part of a small army of volunteers for mental health charity Shout, which since launching in May has held more than , conversations - % mentioning suicide, % depression and % self-harmShareCommentsByEmily RetterSenior Feature Writer:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG NewsDave Bush, we Sue, and daughter Jess, are part of a small army of volunteers for mental health charity Shout "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for the purpose of sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe silence around the kitchen table hangs heavy, punctuated only by the rapid drone of typing across three laptops, and the  intermittent ‘ping’ of messages. Leo the dog scuffles across the floor, maybe wondering when the normal Tuesday evening bustle of cooking tea, and watching Love Island, will begin. It’ll be an hour or so. Dave Bush, we Sue, and daughter Jess, have suspended family le, as they do once or twice a week, to simultaneously chat, via text messages, to complete strangers. Beneath the hush, there’s a lot of noise – fraught words tumbling out in -character snippets strung together in anxious streams, which need every ounce of their attention. As we sit here drinking tea, two of those strangers texting Sue and Jess are revealing they are suicidal.  Sue is chatting to a school-age teenager. “They are struggling, they have been self-harming, they’ve mentioned bullying, and they’ve said they feel suicidal,” she relays, hurriedly looking up for a second as she waits for a reply. Sitting next to her, Jess explains: “My person’s introductory message said they were suicidal. They have a plan, they say they also have the means, but an idea of timeframe isn’t clear yet.” She’s waiting for a reply to tell herit’s tonight. They tell me this situation is far from rare. “It’s a reasonably common conversation to have,” Sue says. “Especially in the evening.” This is Shout, the UK’s first free   text service open to anyone in crisis, run by Mental Health Innovations, and launched in May by the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, and the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, as a means to tackle Britain’s mental health crisis. And crisis it is, according to the figures. In its pilot year, Shout, which has , UK volunteers answering texts, handled , conversations. Today, they’re fielding around  a day. Since its official launch in May, it has held more than ,. Of those, % have mentioned suicide, % depression and % self-harm.  While almost half of texters are aged -, disturbingly, % are aged -. Figures from the annual Good Childhood report this week revealed more children aged - saying they are unhappy than at any point in the last  years. The Bushes, from Cheddington, Bucks, are Shout’s only volunteer family. It helps that they can hold conversations side by side, because it’s heavy going. Sue and Dave joined up in December, and Jess in March, and when we meet, they have held over  conversations. I join them at pm on a weekday. Shout’s busiest time is between pm and am but even in this moment there are  conversations unfolding, plus a queue of four people waiting. When users first text, a complex algorithm assessesthey are high risk. Shout’s volunteers, who have undergone  to  hours of training, are monitored by remote supervisors. Sue, , who works in business development, plucks her school-age teen from the queue, but they take a while to respond to her.  Because they’ve mentioned suicide, she needs to risk assess them, and the wait for a reply is an anxious one. At the sound of a ping she snaps back to her screen. “We have the volume set loud,” she apologises. Meanwhile, Dave, , an actuary, has started chatting. His text is from a young woman struggling as counselling she has been having has ended. But it’s accountant Jess, , who’s found herself confronted with the most immediately challenging situation. Her texter has said they are suicidal right now. The risk assessment has stages, including discovering whether the texter has a plan for suicide, and the means, such as pills or razor blades, whether they have that means with them, and how soon they plan to act. They eventually reply they want to talk to someone about their feelings – a service Shout doesn’t provide. “I have suggested the Samaritans,” says Jess, now waiting anxiously to hearthe texter has called them. In this case, the scenario is made simpler because the texter knows what they need. Dave has experienced a couple where an “active rescue” was needed and emergency services were called. They account for % of conversations. For the first time, I see him become emotional. “They told me they could not keep themselves safe,” he says. “They were self-harming as well.

story: NewsStudent who wasnt used to drinking drowned in uni lake after downing JagerbombsDaniel Williams, , died after going missing during a night out on Reading University campusShareCommentsByCharlie Moloney:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG NewsDaniel was extremely popular with friends and had only started drinking when he was  "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for the purpose of sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA student not used to drinking alcohol drowned in a freezing lake on his campus after downing four Jagerbombs, an inquest heard. Daniel Williams was not a regular drinker and he usually the one helping others to find their way home whenthey had drunk a bit too much, the coroner heard. Tragically there was nobody to take the -year-old home on a night when he appeared like a zombie, having consumed two-and-half times the drink-drive limit at the University of Readingaposs student bar. Mr Williams, known to friends as Dan, attempted to make his way home alone through five inches of fresh snow in the early hours of January . He had become separated from his friends but in his drunken state he accidentally plunged into the icy waters of the Whiteknights lake in Reading, Berks, the coroner ruled.  He was found following an extensive police search, in which boat crews and dog units were sent out. Scores of officers struggled to break the thick ice on top of the lake, just hundreds of yards away from the student union block, so they could enter the chest-high water. The inquest heard that ironically, Daniel was a leguard. The temperature was -C when they waded through treacle-like silt, searching for the missing student. The search ended days later - on February  - when Danaposs body was found, face down with his lower body submerged in the water and his mobile phone and wallet still in his pockets, the inquest in Reading, Berks, heard.  Heidi Connor, Senior Coroner for Berkshire, told the inquest: It seems to me that the circumstances of Danaposs death are tragic but very clear. On the night of January , he went out with friends, doing what students do around the world: he was enjoying himself, drinking alcohol at the student club. He came late in le to alcohol. Drinking alcohol when you are not used to drinking alcohol can have a more dramatic effect, she said. The inquest heard evidence from William Collins, who was one of three other young men who lived with Daniel in their student lodgings near to the university. Mr Collins told the inquest how the four housemates had decided on a night out together on January  and had left their home at pm. He said Daniel, who was wearing a dark-coloured hooded top, had been with him in the Cheese Room, the main dance floor in the newly-refurbished sixty nightclub and bar during the weekly Wednesday Union night. Daniel had ordered four Jagerbombs, a mixture of Jagermeister and an energy drink, for himself, the inquest heard, before he disappeared.  Mr Collins said, in an interview given to police before Daniel was found: It is normal behaviour for Daniel to just go off and leave us during a night and he had done this several times before. We did not see him again. The second year computer sciences student, rom Sutton, Surrey, was later seen by another student, Rebecca Jones. She saw him standing near to the front of the dance floor in the Cheese Room and clinging onto a railing in front of the DJ. Ms Jones said: I saw he was very blank in his face, ashe was staring at us. It appeared ashe was a zombie andyou jumped at him he would not have moved. Nobody saw Daniel leave the student bar and by the evening of January , his housemates had become so concerned they contacted the police and reported him as missing. Detective Constable Andy Matheson, of Thames Valley Police, told the inquest police had upgraded Mr Williams to a high-risk missing person after failing to find him during an overnight search. He told the inquest police had established Mr Williams had left the student bar at .am, as his phone had disconnected from the unionaposs Wi-Fi network and his phone had stopped receiving any signal at .am.  Det. Con. Matheson said: I donapost think anything can be read into that as to when Dan entered the lake.The phone still ed when it came out of the lake. It is possible it [the phone] could still have been connected to the network while it was submerged in the water. Danielaposs parents organised a huge leaflet drop around the university area, appealing for any information about the whereabouts of the blond-haired, blue-eyed student. Volunteers from the local Lowland Search Team also took part in picking through bushes and undergrowth in the hope of finding Daniel and crews from the Royal Berkshire Fire and Rescue Service used their fire boat and waders to search in the lake, three times without success. Police Constable Al Mathieson, leading the search on the ground, said the conditions at the lake, which was not especially deep but was frozen solid and surrounded by a thick layer of silt, meant the focus of the search was on the bank of the lake. Mr Williams was found just shy of an island, which is about  metres from the bank of the lake and the inquest heard the joint investigations of the police and the coroneraposs office discovered there was no sign of any third party involvement, nor any indication that Daniel had been planning to take his own le.  Mrs Connor told his family, who attended the inquest, the young student had no drugs in his system but did have mg of alcohol per ml of blood, two-and-a-half times the drink-driving limit. The coroner said: He did have a relatively high blood alcohol level. In this line of work, I have seen worse than this, but it is undoubtedly high. A post mortem examination gave the cause of death as drowning while under the influence of alcohol and Mrs Connor suggested to the family Mr Williamsapos death should be ruled as an accident. In response, a woman believed to be Danielaposs mother, told the coroner: Contrary to the findings that he had the alcohol, ironically Dan wasnapost a drinker and I feel he was possibly rather naive. Two-and-a-half times the legal limit for driving is a lot, but as you say, there are people who drink a lot more. He did not drink at all until he was  years old. He was a wonderful son. He was genuine, principled, universally loved and liked by everyone who knew him.Ironically, he worked as a le guard. I feel it is tragic because I do not feel that his death should define him, because we are heartbroken.I just hope he did not suffer. Mrs Connor responded: I doubt there is one person in this room who has not been under the influence of alcohol at some point in their le. It certainly does not define Daniel in any way, shape or form.It is just so very sad that this was the outcome in Danaposs case.

Rachel de Rond, , from Haarlem, The Netherlands, was born with natural curls that lost their bounce over time as she became older. In her early twenties she would use shampoo every two days, but when the quality of her hair deteriorated, she dropped that to once a week. This improved her hair slightly, so in August  she discovered the aposno pooapos method, washing hair with a gentle alternative to shampoo, such as apple cider vinegar or water only. Since abandoning the shampoo and other synthetic hair products, she has noticed a considerable dference in the quality of her hair, which has become curlier and more volumized.    She now uses a solution made up of ground nuts and leaves from trees and plants called ayurvedic herbs which she leaves in her hair for  minutes, then rinses out with tap water.Four days later she refreshes her curls with rainwater, which she collects and adds a tiny bit of flaxseed gel on her wet curls. A year after discarding her shampoo bottles, her boyfriend Max van Kessel, , followed her lead hasnapost used shampoo or any product since either.He is now following the water only method.  Rachel says while she was initially worried she would be accused of being aposdirtyapos, she has received a positive response.Strangers love her new hair and they even questionshe has styled her hair with curlers. She said: My scalp didnapost like shampoo and was telling me to stop. Shampoo contains sulphates, which clean everythingand they are very strong and can dry out your skin and hair. I learned about the no-shampoo method because I read an article about a girl who didnapost wash her hair for six to eight weeks when she was on a holiday.  First her hair became quite greasy, but after a few weeks it normalised and in the end her hair was so soft and bouncy. It didnapost look greasy at all. If you saw her, you wouldnapost know that she didnapost washed her hair with shampoo.So, I started reading about the no-shampoo method and I talked about it with my colleague.    Following her advice I started with washing with Aleppo soap and rinsing with apple cider vinegar.My hair and scalp loved it. She has even stopped rinsing her hair with tap water and regularly collects water from the rain due to its softer texture.  Rachel says that on a good washday her hair maintains its curls and she doesnapost have to style her hair for four days at a time. She has since encouraged her boyfriend to try the no shampoo method and he now loves his hair too. I wash my hair once a week with the ayurvedic herbs when I wash my hair, I take my time. title: bard of salford john cooper clarke promises a right good night in dundee visit
story: John Cooper Clarke is ready to rock# and Dundee should be afraid, very afraid.He may be in his older years, but he is not holding back.And the man known as the punk poet has vowed to perform in his unmistakable style – machine gun delivery studded with factory floor language.The rasping Salford accent is still there and the humour as cutting as a surgeon’s scalpel.And for the real devotees, John has teased them by telling the Tele exclusively that he has begun planning his memoirs.In typical fashion he says: “I haven’t kept a f****** diary, but I have got a good memory.“In fact, my memory is long and my vengeance is total.”To the musicians and celebs who have crossed JCC in the past, start praying now because the master could even recall the gig I saw him perform at Strathclyde University in the early s and who was playing on the same bill.For the record, it was Siouxsie and the Banshees – and I couldn’t remember that, despite being a few years younger than the man.Back in the day, John easily recalls everyone being angry young men and women. The hate for Thatcher was pure and the depth of feeling surged through concerts and rallies.He says with a chuckle: “Them were the days.“We thought it was bad then, but everything can get worse, as we see now. It’s a case of careful what you wish for.“I don’t get involved in politics now, like I say when didn’t anyone complain about politicians “Can you point me to a golden era where# everybody liked being ruled  F***ing never!“But there are some real creeps nowadays. But then again I expect the worst from any politician.”So what can fans in Dundee expect when John rolls into town for his show at the city’s Gardyne Theatre on Saturday October  Without missing a beat he fires back: “A right f****** good night!“And they can expect more of the same#and then some. There will be a few classics and there will maybe be a few extra poems.“Then I will add a bit of fun and I can guarantee – solid, copper-plated guarantee – that everybody is going to leave with a smile on their face.”John has fond memories of Dundee and spoke of savouring the atmosphere of a waterfront hotel and added: “I love coming to Scotland and Dundee. I’ve been many times and the reaction of the crowd is great.“I was here last year and saw the VA which is fabulous. I know of DC Thomson and the Sunday Post, the Beano and the Dandy plus Oor Wullie.“Maybe I will buy one of those sculptures.”Posh hotels and venues seem a world away from the clubs and student venues of the s with smoke-filled rooms and plastic tumblers full of warm beer.He used to travel to the shows on public transport and chuckles at the memory.John said: “Yeah, long time ago now, mate. Now I have a driver and I am too old for public transport.“But I still love doing live gigs. It’s smashing. Anywhere where there’s people is greatI’m doing my stuff.“I am working on my book of poems right now. It’s called ‘The Luckiest Man Alive’ and I’m also working on the memoirs. vw, px"  “I am thinking of calling that ‘I Wanna Be Yours’ after the Arctic Monkeys. I just hope to live long enough to finish it.“But I am not finishing up any time soon. I have never even thought about that. I am not retiring, not yet and not in the foreseeable future.”John has the tour to contend with first and is also lining up some television work.And at the age of  there is definitely no holding him back. So look out for many more tours to come from the man who wants to be yours.

title: blether england goalie swift had hands the size o luggies said hector
story: A BwB article in April triggered memories for Rob Boag.For his latest offering, he said: “His name lay dormant, cramped into a crevice of memory for more than half-a-century.“And there he was in an April BwB article – Billy Houliston – and my mind began to release Billy like a genie from a bottle.“Along with Billy, other names surfaced such as Billy Steel, Lawrie Reilly, Jimmy Mason, Willie Waddell and the brilliant Jimmy Cowan.“These are names of legends and ghosts from the past.“I was  years of age in April  when my family were huddled around the wireless listening to England v Scotland at Wembley.BLETHER: #Basher# Billy Houliston lived up to nickname and gave England #discomfort#" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp basher-lived-up-to-nickname-and-gave-england-discomfort embed # secretsCJnnwsFTq" data-secret"sCJnnwsFTq" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"“After the kick-off, England’s attack on Scotland’s goal was relentless and, for the first  minutes, it was Scotland’s goalkeeper Jimmy Cowan v England.“Time after time, just when the commentator was about to call a goal for England, Cowan’s fingertips deflected the ball over the bar or past the post.“Cowan played a blinder.“Then, slowly and surely, Scotland broke free from the English siege and, with the talents and brilliance of Steel, Mason and Waddell and the hustle of Houliston, the Scots began to control the game and dominate England.“It finished a - victory for the Scots. Scotland was a proud and triumphant country that April Saturday in .”Canadian resident Rob continued: “It was almost a decade later that I gained insight into the backdrop of that victory at the famous London venue.“Scottish centre-forward Houliston and England goalkeeper Frank Swt were two characters who had destined roles to play in this international.“On any Saturday night during the late s and s, Frankie Davie’s pub on Lf Road, Lochee, Dundee, was the sports centre of the universe.“And on one of those Saturdays, I moved my way to the bar through a packed house of former sportsmen with a smog of blue tobacco smoke hovering over their heads as they sipped on pints of heavy and relived past glories.“I found the spot where my dad, uncles and their friends held court over sports topics and stories. A pint had been ordered for me, I nodded to everyone and picked up on the thread of conversation.“Swt, Manchester City and England goalkeeper, was the topic.“Hector Duncan was the storyteller, and he said, Swt had a ‘pair o’ hands the size o’ luggies’.“And large hands they were, known in Manchester as the goalie with ‘Frying Pan Hands’.“A big man and a showman, Swt dominated his area and intimidated opposing centre-forwards.“So, who would the SFA select as centre against Frank Swt in the upcoming  Wembley International #Find out next week#.

title: dundee boss james mcpake we believe we have the quality in our team
story: His team’s strength so far this season has been at the back but boss James McPake insists Dundee are going to Tannadice on Friday night to have a go.To date, the Dark Blues have chalked up six clean sheets in their eight competitive outings, but James’ sights in the derby will be focused firmly on taking three points back up to Dens Park.“In a derby the onus is on both teams, you just go,” he said.“You go down there and you have your game plan as a team and we believe we have the quality in our team.“We’ve got strikers that will be worrying them I fully believe that – Kane Hemmings, Andrew Nelson and Danny Johnson.”James is well aware of how well United, with three wins from three, have started their Championship campaign and, like every other manager in the ision, knows the threat posed by free-scoring striker Lawrence Shankland.Any steps he takes to deal with the second tier’s top scorer, however, will be part of an overall plan to cope with the Tangerines as a whole.James added: “It’s stopping Dundee United, that’s what we need to do. It’s not about him. They are a good side with decent players. If we go down there and think it’s all about stopping him, we’ll be really foolish and our game plan will be completely wrong.“He’s had a good start to the season, they’ve had a good start but a derby is a derby and we’ll see what comes on Friday night.“We’ll worry about Dundee, how can we can affect the game.”James has confirmed midfielders Fin Robertson and Jamie Ness will be fit.Teenager Robertson was taken off in the draw with Inverness Caley Thistle at Dens on Saturday but the problem was no more than a touch of cramp.And Ness has recovered from the bug that forced him to miss that one.

title: dundee footballers help raise nearly 1000 for uk based international relief and development charity
story: Footballers in Dundee have helped to raise nearly £, for a UK-based international relief and development charity.Former Morgan Academy pupil Iftekhar Yaqub said the Dadz vs Ladz match played at the DISC last Sunday was a “roaring success”.The money raised will go towards helping war orphans in the Middle East on behalf of the Ummah Welfare Trust.Speaking after the match, Iftekhar said: “The match was a roaring success and the weather for the event was great.“We managed to raise a brilliant total of nearly £, on the day which is great effort on top of the money that had already been raised.”Iftekhar previously revealed that they had already raised nearly £ through the successful Cakesaway campaign in which local organisations – including the Ballhousie Care Group – received donations of cakes.He said he couldn’t thank Dundonians enough for their generosity during the fundraising effort.

title: dundee uniteds calum butcher top tier dundee are the derby favourites
story: Dundee United defender-cum-midfielder Calum Butcher believes “Premiership” Dundee are the favourites ahead of Friday night’s Tannadice Dundee derby.United welcome their city rivals across the street, sitting top of the table and with a % winning record after three games.The Dee, too, are unbeaten with a win and two draws to their name, so far, but sit four points behind the Tangerines.That gap could stretch to seven with a Terrors win in front of the live television cameras and under the Friday night lights.However, following relegation from the top flight last season, Butcher insists the Dark Blues go into the match as the favourites.“It’s a derby. The gap counts for nothing now and there can be no complacency from us,” he said.“Dundee are still a Premiership side that came down last season. They’re going to be very competitive and the derby could change the whole perspective of the league.“We’ve got to be up for it and on it like we have in the last three games now, concentrate like we have and work our socks off.“We need to be on it every week, not just one or two weeks and that’s why it’s vital on Friday we turn up and approach the game properly.“We are underdogs at the end of the day because Dundee are a big side.“Any derby around the world is exactly the same, they mean that little bit more.“Dundee have brought in some really good players in the window and it’s going to be tight all season.“No matter where we are now, that doesn’t mean it’s where we’re going to finish.”The Englishman has been a winner and a loser in Dundee derbies in his first spell at Tannadice from -.He started as United ran out - winners in the Premiership on New Year’s Day  before losing - at Dens Park in the May that year.He believes that experience will stand him in good stead and help others through the game.Though, the -year-old believes it’s their togetherness which will see United through to any success they have on the night.Whether you’re Dundee or United – the Eveningis going derby crazy ahead of this Friday’s meeting between the#Posted by Dundee EveningonWednesday,  August Butcher added: “Experience does help you but, ultimately, it’s a derby.“I’ve had some good results, I’ve had some bad results in derbies,we approach the game like we do every game and are on it from the first whistle, we’ll look after ourselves.“This group of lads are very humble and keep their feet on the ground. There’s no complacency and everyone wants to work hard for each other.“There’s a really good group togetherness here. The manager’s brought some good lads in and there’s no egos.“We’ll work hard and achieve together.“The pre-season helped us get together as a team by having games and playing the way the manager wants to play, it was vital.“The group that was brought in in January had to gel quickly so it was nice in pre-season to get fitness and all that sort of stuff has helped us take that into the league.With some , Arabs set to pack into a sold-out Tannadice on Friday, Butcher thinks that will only add to the occasion.He added: “There was , at Dunfermline and it was fantastic to bring through that number.“They follow us and always turn up in good numbers.“It’s going to be a sell out on Friday night, underneath the lights, so everyone is buzzing for that.“We just need to focus on ourselves and make sure we’re up for the occasion.”

title: james mcpake accepts share of blame for dundee draw with inverness caley thistle
story: Boss James McPake has accepted his share of the blame for Dundee’s below-par performance in Saturday’s goalless draw with Inverness Caley Thistle.After pushing Aberdeen all the way to extra time in the Betfred Cup six days earlier, the Dark Blues looked sluggish as they could not find a way past the Highlanders at Dens Park.While the gaffer was unhappy about that, for him, it was a case of collective responsibility that stretched beyond those on the park.“We’re inconsistent at the minute. We’re getting periods of games where we look really good, then periods where we look not convinced at what we’re doing,” he said.“A lot of that lies with me as well.“I’m changing it, putting people on and changing shape, so I’ll go away and, as a staff, we’ll have a look at that and seewe can pinpoint where we’re going wrong as well.”He refused to use either the sticky conditions or the fact his team had taken Aberdeen to extra time as a reason for the drop in levels.“There was no issue with that at all. There are no excuses. Teams will come here and make it stuffy. We need to create an atmosphere.“The atmosphere was created last week because we were in Aberdeen’s faces and there was an extra , Aberdeen fans.“We could have created that same atmosphere by being the same Dundee team that came out on Sunday last week and had a right go at Aberdeen.“That’s the bit I need to get right, me and my staff – and we will.”There was an injury scare when teenage midfielder Fin Robertson came off in the second half after feeling his hamstring.Dundee are confident, however, the problem was no more than cramp and they expect the -year-old to be available for Friday night’s derby at Tannadice.Likewise, fellow-midfielder Jamie Ness is expected toafter missing out on Saturday because of a bought of sickness.“Jamie had a bit of sickness. That’s football, you get injuries, you get illnesses, you get suspensions,” added the manager.“It’s disappointing but again that’s not an excuse as to why we weren’t at it and why we failed to break down Inverness.”Dundee’s few hundred remaining tickets for Friday night went on general sale today and are expected to be snapped up quickly.That will make the first derby in over three years a complete sell-out despite it being shown live on television.

story: Ryan Hedges says he was impressed with Aberdonian Terry Taylor at Wales’ Algarve training camp in the summer.Taylor, , left the Pittodrie youth set-up for Wolverhampton Wanderers in .The midfielder is skipper of the Under-s at Molineux.He played in the first team’s win over Manchester City in the Premier League Asia Trophy in July.Despite previously featuring at youth level for Scotland, Taylor qualies for Wales through his mother.And winger Hedges says he was impressed by the teen’s ability – ability which has seen him called into the Welsh U contingent for upcoming matches against Belgium and Germany.Hedges said: “In the summer we had a training camp and I met up with Terry.“I just spoke to him about Aberdeen before I moved.
